p: The efficacy of cancer immunotherapy relies on the generation of specific anti-tumour CD8 + T cells that recognize peptides presented on the major histocompatibility complex I (MHC-I) [8]. Effective anti-tumour activity requires fast T cell mediated responses, which is highlighted for example by clinical success with the chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells targeting CD19 in B cell malignancies [9]. Importantly, it has been shown that the cooperation of CD4 + and CD8 + T cells is required for efficient anti-tumour immunity to occur [10]. Indeed, CD4 + T cells provide signals that improve the functionality of CD8 + T cells within the tumour microenvironment (TME) [11] and their depletion prior to tumour challenge results in complete loss of tumour rejection in murine tumour models [12].
